DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Backed Envoy: Noriega Should be Tried in Panama
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with session ending, council unable to decide which gov't to recognize, countries denounce U.S. action. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The designated U.N. envoy of the U.S.-installed government in Panama said Thursday that if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is captured, he should not be extradited to the United States but tried in Panama. Later Thursday, the 15-member Security Council debated the Panama invasion, with many governments denouncing the United States. But the council could not decide which government to recognize _ Noriega's or the U.S.-backed government of Guillermo Endara _ and no further meeting was scheduled. Both sides have sought to have their ambassadors accredited to the United Nations, which can recognize only one of them. Eduardo Vallarino, a self-exiled Panamanian businessman, was nominated as Panama's U.N. ambassador by Endara's government, installed by U.S. troops at a military base Wednesday. Vallarino told a news conference that Panama's Constitution prohibits extradition. If Noriega is captured by occupying U.S. forces, he said, Panama would protest his extradition to face narcotics charges in the United States. ``I would have to say that probably the Panamanian government would have to protest,'' Vallarino said in answer to a question. ``If Noriega is apprehended by the authorities in Panama, he will have to be duly charged and tried in Panama,'' Vallarino said. But he added that the situation is ``irregular.'' He also said the Endara group had not sought U.S. intervention in Panama, but welcomed it. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, in his first comment on the U.S. intervention, said: ``The position of the U.N. for the last 45 years is that we always regret the use of force.'' He added that he hoped the Security Council would reach agreement ``to restore order in Panama.'' He spoke before the council reconvened at the request of Nicaragua, which along with the Soviet Union condemned the U.S. invasion Wednesday night. Nicaragua seeks council condemnation of the U.S. military action, but the United States and Britain could veto any critical resolution. Discussion of credentials by the Security Council is rare and has not occurred in recent memory. The Noriega government is not represented in the United Nations because the previous envoy, Leonardo Kam, has been promoted to foreign minister. That government is trying to accredit as U.N. envoy its ambassador to the European Community, Mirla Bellavita. U.N. diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they expected the council would not take up the question of competing claims. They said the council was likely to ask the secretary-general for a report. The secretary-general, however, had said he hoped the council would decide the question. The question ultimately could be passed on to the General Assembly, diplomats said. But according to the U.N. Charter, the 159-nation assembly cannot take up a question while it is under consideration by the council, without a request by the council. The U.N. legal department is studying the question. The Organization of American States in Washington declined to recognize the Endara government Wednesday. Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia in late 1978 posed a similar problem for the General Assembly, which refused to recognize the Vietnam-installed government and still recocognizes the ousted Cambodian government in exile, headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and his allies. Speakers from 10 countries addressed the council Thursday, and all except El Salvador denounced the U.S. invasion, although some also criticized Noriega. El Salvador did not specifically endorse the U.S. action, but criticized Noriega's undermining of democracy and self-determination in Panama. Peru was especially vocal in condemning ``flagrant violation of Panama's sovereignty'' in what it called ``a grim updating of imperialist practices.'' Other speakers included Algeria, Brazil, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland and Libya. In the first debate Wednesday night, only Britain staunchly backed the U.S. action.
